instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01598: What is 820-01598? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.CD3217: What is CD3217? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook won’t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PPVBAT_G3H_CONN: What is PPVBAT_G3H_CONN? This is the where the battery’s power rail connects to the motherboard. .
definitions.PPVBAT_G3H_CHGR_R: What is PPVBAT_G3H_CHGR_R? This is a power rail between the battery and a current sense resistor before the battery power feeds current to the rest of the machine. .
definitions.PP1V2_AWAKE: What is PP1V2_AWAKE? The PP1V2_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides 1.2 volts and is associated with the machine's awake state and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP3V_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V_G3H_RTC? PP3V_G3H_RTC is a 3v power rail present when the machine is in a G3H mechanical off state that powers the RTC circuit. .
definitions.A1706: What is A1706? A1706 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3071, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00239, 820-00923..
definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.A1989: What is A1989? A1989 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2018, 2019 with EMC 3124, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00850..
definitions.A2141: What is A2141? A2141 is a model number for a 16 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2019 with EMC 3347, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01700..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> works only with battery
threads.message:
Hello everyone.
   Got this laptop yesterday, castomer says "mac doesn't charging and external usb drives can not be recognized"
Mac still powers on, everything works, exept usb-c potrs. With plugged in charger usb-c meter shows 5 volt steady on one of the ports, and 5 volt rebooting every 2 seconds on other port. No traces of liquid or corrosion on board.
   I found out that <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> is shorted. After changing <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> (<CHIP>CD3217</CHIP>) both ports has stable 5 volts with no rebooting. Then i changed <CHIP>U2980</CHIP>. Now Im getting 20 volts, 0.05 amps, board not booting, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.2, SLPS2R/AWAKE signals present, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> missing.
   With battery mac still turns on, and external devices can be recognized now. But still not charging.

Changed <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>/40, checked all resistors around <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and both <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP>, they are all fine.

I'd appreciate any advice

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> works only with battery
threads.message:
<CHIP>U2890</CHIP> has important information; don't see <CHIP>U2980</CHIP> in schematic.
There is USB-C firmware.

So the Mac was working before with battery and now doesn't work at all?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> works only with battery
threads.message: It still works with battery, and now it recognizes flash drives and other external devices. But doesn't recognize the charger, and won't start with charger only when battery disconnected

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> works only with battery
threads.message:
I'm not sure, please clarify.
It works with battery alone and charger alone: doesn turn on with both connected?
Post <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage with both charger and battery connected.
Check <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7065</TRANSISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> works only with battery
threads.message:
Sorry for my english :)

If battery is connected without charger - mac turns on, not recognizing charger, not charging the battery. Other functions works good. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 10.6 volt
If battery is connected and charger plugged in - all same
If battery disconnected - mac doesn't turns on, 20 volts, 0.05 amps, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> missing, awake/slps2r present, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.3 volts

<TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> already changed. PPDCIN 20 volts, <SIGNAL>CHGR_GATE_Q1</SIGNAL> 41 volts, <SIGNAL>CHGR_GATE_Q2</SIGNAL> 0.2 volts
<TRANSISTOR>Q7065</TRANSISTOR>: <SIGNAL>PPVBAT_G3H_CHGR_R</SIGNAL> - 12.2 volts, <SIGNAL>CHGR_BGATE</SIGNAL> - 12.2 volts <SIGNAL>PPVBAT_G3H_CONN</SIGNAL> - 0
If battery is disconnected - <TRANSISTOR>Q7065</TRANSISTOR> should  be opened? Because it's a P-channel, and the gate is high, so it's closed. I changed <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> already twice. <CAPACITOR>C7064</CAPACITOR> is not shorted...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> works only with battery
threads.message: Post voltage and diode mode to ground on SCL/SDA lines of battery bus, before and after <TRANSISTOR>Q6950</TRANSISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> works only with battery
threads.message:
Before <TRANSISTOR>Q6950</TRANSISTOR>
SCL voltage 3.2 volts, 0.8 in diode mode
SDA voltage 3.2 volts, 0.8 in diode mode
After <TRANSISTOR>Q6950</TRANSISTOR>
SCL voltage 1.8 volts, 0.47 in diode mode
SDA voltage 1.8 volts, 0.47 in diode mode

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> works only with battery
threads.message:
With both charger and battery connected, charger is not recognized on system report?
Did you try another charger?
<SIGNAL>PCH_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> stays high?

Check <SIGNAL>LDO_RTC</SIGNAL> at <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>, with charger only (no battery).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> works only with battery
threads.message:
With charger connected it is not recognized on system report
tryed 3 different chargers
<SIGNAL>PCH_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> is 0 with charger only, and 0.8-1.5 volts when mac is turned on with battery
<SIGNAL>LDO_RTC</SIGNAL> with charger only 1.5 volts

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> works only with battery
threads.message: Check if <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> is good.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> works only with battery
threads.message: It's good. 0 Ohm, 3.3 volts on both pins are present

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> works only with battery
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7800</CHIP> outputs:
<SIGNAL>LDO_CORE</SIGNAL> 1.5 v
<SIGNAL>PP0V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> 0.8 v
<SIGNAL>PP3V_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> 3.0 v
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_AWAKE</SIGNAL> 1.2 v
<SIGNAL>PMU_LDO3_OUT_R</SIGNAL> 1.8 v
<SIGNAL>CPU_C10_GATE_L</SIGNAL> 0 v
<SIGNAL>PP1V_S0SW</SIGNAL> 0 v
<SIGNAL>LDO_RTC</SIGNAL> 1.5 v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_PMU_VDDMAIN</SIGNAL> 3.3 v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_AWAKE</SIGNAL> 3.3 v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 0 v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> works only with battery
threads.message:
Just in case, try DFU.

Did you put back original <CHIP>U2890</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> works only with battery
threads.message:
DFU doesn't help.
   But i found something interesting: i puted back original <CHIP>U2890</CHIP>, and 20 volts is gone, looks like this chip is dead, because there was a short circuit before on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL>. And i decided to try this chip from another donor board.
   So i've tryed <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - non of them is working. No 20 volts. And only <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> from <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> is switching to 20 volts, but not charging.
Is there a chanse that there is compability between different boards, and <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> should be exactly from same board?
   Unfortunatelly i don't have this one now :(

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> works only with battery
threads.message:
I already explained that in first post.
Search on Internet, if someone uploaded such file.
If not, find a donor 01598 board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> works only with battery
threads.message: Sorry, I didn't really get it. You mean i need to search the firmware for <CHIP>U2980</CHIP> in internet?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> works only with battery
threads.message: Yes and it is <CHIP>U2890</CHIP>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> works only with battery
threads.message: Oh, my mistake, it's a typo...<CHIP>U2890</CHIP> of course. I didn't find any. I have a CH341A programmer, do you think it is possible to read the firmware from original chip using this type of programmer? Or i should buy some special tool for this? Im at the small island in the middle of Indian ocean, no chance to find donor 01598 here...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> works only with battery
threads.message: Ok, so i've tryed to read the data from original <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> and looks like it worked. I flash the original firmware to the <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> from <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> mac, and 20 volts is gone. DFU mode sucsessfuly reviving macbook, but still not charging, and no 20 volts now with original firmware...Board still turns on with battery

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> works only with battery
threads.message:
You should get a known good firmware from 01598 for <CHIP>U2890</CHIP>.
Is the only way to discard a problem of it.
